PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: John B. Dickey
Address: Langton
Birthplace: Musquodoboit, N.S.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1876
Where did you set up housekeeping? S.E. 13 R. 2 W. 4, Poplar Grove, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? On an adjoining farm.
For how many people did you prepare meals? One, and sometimes two.
How far was it to your nearest store? 20 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, corn syrup, dried apples, tea, yeast, rolled oats, cornmeal, salt, rice

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong
In what quantities did you buy it? 25 lb. each
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.25
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? (Yes)

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   **Summer**
   - Breakfast: Oatmeal porridge with cream and sugar, boiled, butter, jam, syrup, tea, eggs, muffins.
   - Dinner: Fried potatoes, fried pork, baked beans, apple sauce, bread, butter, tea.
   - Supper: Fried potatoes, bread, butter, jam, tea, eggs, milk.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There was much less variety in the earliest days.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When we left the farm in 1949.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above; quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

There was a cheese factory about 35 mi. away where whole cheeses could be bought at 8¢ per lb. People picked wild fruit for jam or jelly—raspberries, black currants, blueberries, choke cherries, high bush cranberries.

Coal oil and matches were two very important things to be bought in those years. There were no substitutes for them.

People often got sick and better, just went without till they had milk or sugar in sugar or syrup probably.
